participants.participant: Fulvio Conti, Chief Executive Officer and General Manager
Luigi Ferraris, Administration, Finance and Control
Andrea Brentan, Chief Executive Officer, Endesa

plist.p: Good morning. Good morning, everybody. Welcome to our annual meeting. With two starting points, two remarks. The financial crisis doesn't look to have deterred a lot of bankers that I see here. Healthy and wealthy bankers, welcome to all of you.

The financial crisis has not impacted on our business and we're here to demonstrate what is the theme of our presentation. We have a resilient, growing, cash generating company to offer to all of you. Today Luigi, who is our Chief Financial Officer here, will present the robust set of 2009 results, which we have delivered to all of our stakeholders and stakeholders despite the challenging economic environment world wide. We are pleased to report continued growth in our profitability, improved balance sheet strength which has enabled us to provide stable, high-yielding dividends for all of our shareholders. After Luigi's presentation, I will take you through the key points of our 2010, 2014 plan with details on Endesa outlined by Andrea Brentan, who is acting as CEO of the company.

Also I'm pleased to confirm that together with Luigi, Andrea and myself, we have here our Chairman Mr. Piero Gnudi, there he is, Mr. Borja Prado, the Chairman of Endesa, a lot of directors of the company and board members. The divisional managers will be available of course to take on any questions you might have during the presentation.

Now, let me start with the presentation here. There it goes. I would like to start by reminding you the position that Enel has achieved in the international energy markets. I'm proud to say, Enel is now one of the largest European and International electricity and gas player.

The transformation we have undergone in recent years has given us five core strengths, which I believe position us very well for the future. We gain a leading position in our core markets thanks to our strong domestic business, combined with our International expansion strategy. We continue to demonstrate strong operational performance across all markets, with focus on efficiencies. We have significantly strengthened our financial position thanks to our successful rights issue and recent bond issuance.

With the successful integration of Endesa, we have completed the transformational path of the Group, which will enable us to fully focus on our future priorities. Our technological and geographical mix gives us strong resilience against economic cycles, and therefore we are well positioned to develop future organic growth opportunities as market conditions improve. The Group robust performance in 2009 is evidence that we are delivering on our strategy despite challenging economic environment.

With this accomplishment, Enel continues to look towards the future. We have developed the strategy that will present new opportunities, which we believe will place Enel at the forefront of the industry over the next five years.

Now, in particular, our vision can be summed up in the five key priorities that you see indicated in this chart. First, we will maintain our leadership position in our core markets, where we have developed an integrated presence along the energy value chain. In particular, we will focus on our domestic markets, Italy and Iberia as well as Latin America, Russia, Slovakia, Romania, France and all of our existing geographies in renewables. They will continue to be the target of our select investments, aimed at maintaining our cost leadership and the best practices sharing.

Second, as far as consolidation and integration is concerned, we will leverage on organic investments to enhance our leadership position, as well as on a relevant synergies program to extract value from our operations.
Third, we will continue to invest in efficiency improvements and cost-savings initiatives, keeping service quality for our customer base of more than 61 million customers worldwide a must.

Fourth, renewables will continue to be a key pillar on our strategy. We will strengthen our footprint through the integration of Endesa's renewables assets into Enel Green Power, as we will explain later during the presentation. Moreover, we will continue to promote new technologies, investing in particular in carbon capture sequestration, hydrogen, solar, smart grids, emobility while preparing the grounds for the forthcoming nuclear era in Italy.

Last but not least, we will continue to implement initiatives aimed at ensuring our financial stability, cash flow improvement, CapEx optimization and asset disposals will allow us to confirm our commitment to reduce net debt and maintain our A credit rating.
To discuss all of these items in greater detail, let's start with our leadership in strategic markets.

Enel has selected the market highlighted here as a key to the execution of the strategy. To maintain our leadership in the areas of thermal generation, supply and distribution of energy, the Group will continue to invest in improving the mix of technologies and the quality of services to the end customers. Moreover, we will enhance the technological standard of the networks leveraging on innovative solutions such as smart grids.

As of today, Enel benefits from a technological mix which is already about 45% CO2 free. In this regard, we will continue to utilize a unique combination of assets across geographies with the aim to invest both in free CO2 technologies and innovative energy sources. Thanks to this mix, Enel is already prepared to cope with past 2012 CO2 challenges.

Let's now move to our second key priority, consolidation and integration. Our cumulative investment program has been fervently revised as respect to the old plan, mainly due to a deterioration in the macroeconomic outlook. In this program, we'll continue to include projects which we consider key pillars of our margin growth even in an unfavorable economic cycles. These projects are mainly in Italy's things like clean coal and gas mainstream facilities, renewables and some initial nuclear initiatives.

In Spain and Latam, focus on renewables and efficiency projects for the plan. In Russia, CCGTs and gas extraction in networks. In the areas where we are already present, maintenance investments will continue to prioritize service quality and customer care. Let me also underline that this program, in case of further slowdown in demand, will offer us flexibility at the tune of three billion euros for project that can be either cancelled, postponed, without compromising our profitability during this plan.

Moving on to integration, let me underline the integration program with Endesa is noteworthy in terms of speed of execution and total benefits achieved so far. In fact, as of the end of 2009, we have already recorded about 500 million euros of synergies, real ones – hard ones, which is about 13% better than the original target, by the way.

We also involved, in this program, 14 areas of improvement, both at Enel and Endesa, and more than 30 initiatives in which we are currently working on assessing potential for further improvements. With that in mind, I'm pleased to confirm on commitments to increase our 2012 target to more than one billion euro of higher cash contribution generated from our EBITDA and CapEx optimization.

Let me move to the third pillar of our strategy, operational excellence. We will continue to focus our efforts on both working capital optimization and operating expenses. At the end of 2009, we reduced our cumulative working capital by 600 million euros, which is 448 million higher than the first nine months of the year. We also achieved, so far, an EBITDA improvement of about 430 million, of which 200 million are recurring. This cumulates at about 830 up to 2011 – 830 million, I mean.

Furthermore, we continue to remain committed to developing this program which not only improves cash flows but also serve as an industrial tool to implement best-in-class processes, such as international best practice sharing, procurement activities, customer management and lean operations, amongst other. On top of this, let me underline that Endesa is also developing its own Zenith program which will deliver about 240 million cash available by 2012.

Let's look, now, at the fourth key priority, renewables and innovation. After the recently-announced integration of Endesa's Spanish renewable assets into EGP, we have completed the process of consolidating all of the Group's main renewable activities into one single unit. In particular, I'm proud to state that we have created a robust industrial player, which will have a key role in both the economies of Italy and Spain.

The numbers indicated in this charts give you a clear picture of what EGP is today, one of the world's largest renewable operators in terms of production and installed capacity. EGP will build up its future on a diversified geographical presence with a unique mix of large-scale renewable technologies, not only wind and mini-hydro but also geothermal and solar. The combination of all of this results in a good hedge versus regulatory changes and ultimately in the stability of cash flows that sustain growth.

Finally, EGP has further increased its flexibility, enhancing its pipeline from 21.7 gigawatt to 30.6 gigawatt, therefore creating to itself an important chance to capture new opportunities. An additional expansion of 3.5 gigawatt is already planned during the plan.

Following slide – well, this is something I'm particularly proud to report back to you, innovation. Among our aims, I want to underline our commitment in continuing to develop all technologies connected to the CO2 capture and storage, oxycombustion, high-efficiency coal plants, hydrogen and thermodynamic solar with the Archimede project.

On top of this, we believe that the future of the world will rely more and more on the proactive management of electricity grids. That is why we decided to be the pioneers in the deployment of digital electricity meters. The future will be continuing deployment of digital electricity meters, mainly in Spain and Latam, implementing smart grids and demand side management, enabling e-mobility and developing nuclear projects.

My take in this is that electricity power is the solution for most of our demand in growth of economies and welfare. And for that reason, we strongly support research and development projects up to the point of allocating one billion euros to support innovation in the next five years. Once again, it is Enel's goal to be at the forefront of the deployment of possible industrial initiatives to improve the quality of life of our communities and to enhance our long-term profitability.

Let me now move to our final key strategic priority, financial stability. First, financial stability for us basically means delivering cash flow optimization and the disposal plan that we are committed to back in March 2009. Let me recap what we have already done. The combination of the sale of the Italian high-voltage grid, 80% stake in a gas low-pressure network, 50% stake in our upstream gas project in Russia, as well as other minor disposals in Latin America, have allowed us to raise 3.2 billion, both in terms of cash and the net debt deconsolidation.

Also, we confirm our commitment to generate about 7 billion of cash or further net debt reduction by the end of this year. In addition to the disposal of the minority stake in Enel Green Power, which I will discuss in more details in the next slide, we continue to work on the disposal of the Spanish high-voltage grid. At this regard, let me update you by indicating that we have opened the data room and the due diligence process that is undergoing is almost close to finish. Therefore, I do expect the disposal to be completed before the end of June – this June.

With regard to other non-strategic asset disposal, we have started the tender offer for our operation in Bulgaria and we have already received for that specific very well-performing asset unsolicited indication of interest. Also, we have just signed the agreement with Mytilineos Group to sell the Endesa's Greek operations for a total consideration of 140 million. Other peripheral assets are earmarked for disposal, and this will be disclosed, when appropriate, during the year.

Let me move, now, to the disposal minority stake in EGP. I would like to confirm that this is our intention, here, to dispose of this stake by the end of 2010, by 2010 at the latest. Obviously, the latest includes the earliest and we'll do our best in this regard.

In particular, given our current market condition and the overall market conditions, we believe that an IPO represents the preferred option for maximizing value for shareholders. In fact, we're now working on the filing of the offering documents which should occur by the end of April. This may be the reason why a lot of bankers are showing up this morning. No surprise, welcome. The beauty parade will be starting soon. After this, the listing of EGP in Milan and Madrid will be implemented during the year.

In parallel with this process, we continue to maintain contacts with potential strategic investors with an industrial vision. I stress, with an industrial vision, we're not looking for financial partners. At this regard, let me underline that, while we cannot exclude potential opportunities arising from the above contacts, the above-mentioned contacts, we're now opening the IPO process maintaining – still maintaining the potential combination of the two options.
Now, before handing over to Luigi for the 2009 results, let me summarize the impact of all the strategic actions that I've just tried to report back to you.

Combined actions on the Zenith program, the synergies between Enel and Endesa will contribute to cumulative consolidated operating cash flow of about 65 billion euros through 2014. This cash flow will support our investment program, the debt service and the dividends paid to the Group's minorities and to Enel's shareholders. In terms of dividends, let me confirm that we will continue to distribute 60% of our net ordinary income.

The balance between free cash flow from operations and the positive contribution of our disposal plan will lead to a net cash available for the debt reduction of about 12 billion by the end of 2014. All of this will allow the Groups to target a consolidated net debt of about 39 billion by the end of 2014, while maintaining our A category essential to our strategy.
Let me hand it over to Luigi for the results and all of the details of those results. Luigi, the floor is yours.

Thank you, Fulvio. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Before going into the 2009 number in details, let me underline not only the robustness and resilience of our results but also the strong and active management undertaken during 2009 focused both on reduction and requalification of our net debt. You will see the effects of all of these later on in my presentation but I would like to emphasize that neither debts nor liquidity is an issue for this Group.

Also, let me remind you that, in the first – second half 2009, Endesa results are fully consolidated on a line-by-line basis. But now let's have a look at the numbers. First, I am going to give you some financial highlights, then I will take you through the 2009 financial results ending with our current long-term debt maturity profile.

Group EBITDA net of non-recurring items, increased by 10.5% to about 15.6 billion euro, or 2.3% up considering second half with Endesa consolidated at 67%. 2009 Group net income of about 5.4 billion euro includes mainly the positive contribution of some extraordinary items for a total amount of about 1.4 billion euro. The most significant ones are the following. 970 million euro Acciona put option, 295 million euro capital gain related to the assets sold to Terna, 68 million euro capital gain related to the SeverEnergia stake sold to Gazprom.

Let me remind you, again, that these amounts are not to be included in the ordinary income and therefore are not to be considered as part of our dividend. Excluding extraordinary items, Group net income is approximately 4 billion, 9% up versus last year.
Now, moving to the following chart, EBIT increased by 12.7% due to higher EBITDA partially balanced by higher D&A for changes in the consolidation mainly of Endesa, OGK-5 and Muntenia in Romania.

Our net financial charges decreased to 1.7 billion euro. This is mainly the effect of higher income resulting from the fair value of Acciona put option for 970 million euro recorded at the end of this – during this year, lower interest charges of 362 million mainly due to lower average debt and lower cost of debt, which was 5% at the end of December.
The Group's tax rate increased from 9.2% in 2008 to 27.8% in 2009. On a normalized basis, 2009 tax rate would be equal to 32.6% or 1% less than last year.

Before going through the EBITDA composition, on chart number 16, you will find an update on our hedging strategy, in particular on forward electricity sales. In Italy, we have hedged 100% of our 2010 production at an average base load price of 75 euro per megawatt hour.

As regards 2011, we have hedged 20% at an average base load price of around 75 euro per megawatt hour and we have also a contracted portfolio of no price-sensitive customers, which are about to be automatically renewed during 2010 for another 20% at premium price against market conditions. That is again 75 euro per megawatt hour. This is the results of ordinary rolling over commercial condition we are recognizing to our customer base.

As far as Spain is concerned, we are 100% hedged for 2010 and about 40% for 2011, improving the total amount hedged versus last year that, let me remind you, at this point in time was only 25% for 2010. The average price for 2010 is in the range of 50, 55 euro per megawatt hour and for 2011 is higher than the Spanish forward curve.

In Latin America, we are about 70% hedged for 2010 and 65% for 2011. Finally, in Slovakia, we are 100% hedged for 2010 and 55% for 2011, nearly doubling the amounts hedged versus last year. This has been obtained at an average price equal to 53 euro per megawatt hour for 2010 and about 57 for 2011.

All of this will help to explain our EBITDA evolution in chart number 17, which gives you an overview of all of our operations. I will go through the EBITDA of each of our division in detail starting from GEM, Generation and Energy Management Italy on chart number 18.

The generation margin increased by 243 million euro, mainly due to forward contracts and a more favorable fuel mix, which have more than offset the decline in volumes. The improvement of 78 million euro in trading margin is the result of favorable gas sourcing, mainly recorded during the first half of 2009.

The margin in the ancillary services has decreased by 211 million euro, largely because of lower electricity demands. Additional items are negative for 322 million euro and they refer to the capital gain of the assets sold to Trento last year for a total consideration of 328 million euro.

Let's, now, briefly look at the fuel cost evolution on the following chart. Net of ancillary service, the UE margin in the domestic or thermal generation increased to 28 euro per megawatt hour from 23 euro per megawatt hour in 2008, so 5 euro per megawatt hour up, mainly due to our forward sales, commodity hedging activities and the start of the operation of the clean coal second units in Torre Nord in the unit close to Rome.
The overall generation unit margin net of ancillary services is about 46 euro per megawatt hour versus 37 of last year, mainly thanks to the increase in the hydro production.

In the annexes you have details of the EBITDA evolution regarding our market Services and Holding division, while I'm now highlighting our domestic Infrastructure and Networks division on the following chart. Well, EBITDA totaled almost 4 billion euro in this division with an increase of about 7% versus last year. The main items are the following.

The increase of 39 million euro in the energy price – in the energy margin, mainly due to positive price components; lower connection fees of 58 million euro, mainly due to the unfavorable economic environment. In the future, we will not be anymore affected by this reduction since the authority has recently introduced a mechanism that recovers distributors from possible losses they might incur in 2010 and in 2011 having as a reference the connection fee amounts of 2006.
As far as other is concerned, bear in mind that we recorded 295 million euro capital gain from the sale of the high voltage grid to Terna.

Moving now to the following chart on international operation, well, here we have an EBITDA of about 1.4 billion euro with an increase of 36% versus last year, or 30% net of the capital gain of the disposal of SeverEnergia, which is equal to 68 million euro. The results of this strong performance are substantially the following.

In the Centrel area we continue to see an increasing contribution from our Slovenské elektrárne, which in this year has totaled 100 million euro of positive variance versus last year. Let me also stress the total EBITDA of this company has been equal to 826 million euro at the end of 2009.

Russia contributed for 176 million euro in the period, of which 68 million euro related to the SeverEnergia capital gain, as I said before, and 100 million euro to the OGK-5. In OGK-5, the unit energy margin improved both in power and capacity markets.

But, before moving on to the following division, let's have a quick look at the Russian activities on the following chart, number 22. OGK-5 reported in 2009 an EBITDA of 183 million euro, or 50% up versus last year. This is basically the result of a higher unit margin due to higher tariffs, increasing capacity payments and efficiencies.

Let's now focus on Endesa results in the following chart again. First of all, let me remind you that the numbers we report in these slides included the decrease in the Iberian operation result from the application of the Enel Group accounting principles.

Let's analyze the business now. In Iberia, the hedging strategy with customer that has supported unitary revenues at level of about 60 euro per megawatt hour, the removal of CO2 clawback as well as a very competitive unitary electricity cost have substantially offset the decline in generation volumes showing an – basically a zero growth or in line with last year.

In Latin America in the Generation business, the unit margin improvement in Chile, the higher sale price in Colombia and the higher hydro outputs in Peru more than balanced lower prices in Argentina and Brazil. Taking into account all of these effects, Generation business EBITDA grew by about 14% versus last year.

In the distribution business, the combined effect of some negative regulatory changes in Chile, coupled with a negative currency conversion rate, have been partially offset by the positive contribution of Brazil.

And, now, let's review Enel Green Power on chart number 24. Before entering into details, let me underline that these are EGP figures on a stand-alone basis, which differ from the ones reported in Enel's financial statements due to some consolidation adjustments and other effects.

Let me highlight, again, that EGP results have been very positive, showing a 6% increase versus 2008. More specifically, the growth components are, 52 million euro from Italy, mainly driven by higher production, 14 million euro from the Americas, a slight decline in Iberia, mainly because of the decrease in the average energy price in Spain, and 8 million improvement in the other operation in the rest of Europe.

And, now, we remain focused on Enel Green Power, let me spend few words about the integration of the Spanish assets that we have just announced this morning, and I am on the following chart. As you know, we have substantially completed – or started to finalize the integration process of all the Spanish renewable assets into one single entity in Spain.

In this regards, we have outlined a reorganization that you see represented in this chart. In particular, the Iberian assets will be managed through a company 60% controlled by Enel Green Power and 40% by Endesa, and fully consolidated on a line-by-line basis by Enel Green Power. The new company will manage all present and future renewable activities in the Iberian market.

This successful implementation process will allow Enel Green Power to enhance its position in the Spanish renewal market capturing also higher EBITDA and organic growth opportunities, mainly thanks to the new pipeline now headed up. We believe that such reorganization shows our capability to generate value through integration and exploitation of synergies.

As far as our net debt evolution is concerned you'll see in the next chart that our overall net debt stood at about 50.9 billion euros at the end of 2009. The main items on net debt evolution are the following, on the negative side we recorded mainly the acquisition of a further 25% stake in Endesa for about 12 billion euros including 100% debt consolidation and the renewable assets sold to Acciona. On the positive side, first the rights issue for 8 billion euros, about 3.2 billion euros from the delivered asset disposal and about 2.2 billion euro from the extra-peninsular tariff deficit reclassification.

To conclude, let me give you a quick update on where we stand in terms of maturity profile of our long-term debt. Well, the successful European and US dollar institutional bond, as well as the retail bond issuance, just finalized, has led us to achieve the desired effect of diversifying our credit investor base, shift the focus from bank loans to bonds as a long-term structural way of financing our long-term assets, lengthening the average maturity of long-term debt and securing an adequate fixed/floating rate ratio.

In addition to our well-spread maturity profile, our liquidity position is supported by the availability of committed credit line aimed at serving management of working capital taking also into account cash and cash equivalents, our Group liquidity position amounts to 21 billion euros.

Also, let me add that 7 billion euros of these committed credit lines currently available are maturing in 2010. This is why we are already considering their renegotiation in order to use them as a backup treasury tool with no intention, whatsoever, to finance long-term activities.
Finally, the expected cash in from disposal and the tariff deficit accrued by Endesa will further strengthen our consolidated liquidity position.
Thank you for your attention and now let me hand over to Fulvio Conti for the strategic plan 2010-2014.

Thank you, Luigi. Let me now move into our strategic plan by division. I think, first, we have to discuss the assumption. We have indicated to you back in March last year a demand assumption which has not yet shown to be the right one. We are revising it to reflect the current market consensus. As you might remember, we projected for 2009 a demand growth of adjusted 0.3%. Indeed, it was beaten by actual. Actual was minus 4.5%. I concede that that has happened but this has not deterred our performance. Even though we have reduced the volumes, we have increased the results.

Now, on the new demand assumption that you see reported over here, which I do believe is meeting market consensus, is considering a gradual recovery moving from a bare minimum recorded in 2009. This recovery trend has been confirmed, by the way, by the first two months of the year where we have seen demand increasing to the tune of 2% in Italy, 3% in Spain, 7% in Russia, and so forth and so on.

Let me start with the Italian operations first. This is very, very important for all of you analysts that you've been asking the same question over the last 10 years, and I've been responding to you Italy is an island and I will continue to report to you that Italy is an island. Let me explain the reason why it is an island.

The Italian wholesale power market is influenced by the evolution of gas price and by the remuneration of the investment in power generation, spark spread, all of you analysts, you know better than me. Gas oversupplies conditions of 2009 did not have any impact on 2009 power price in Italy. As a matter of fact, the decrease in power price against 2008 was only a direct consequence of the drop in the oil price, being Italian gas price based on long-term supplies directly linked to oil pricing. We do not expect major changes from this point of view in the future years.

As European gas spot prices which, as you know, have been suffering significant decrease in 2009, are not impacting the Italian long-term gas supply contracts, spot market in Italy accounts for only few percentage points out of the total consumption. The Italian generation mix is also characterized by few – very few coal plants, ours. And very expensive technologies, like oil and gas plants, our competitors.

Since 2003, about 23 gigawatt of new CCGT capacity has been built or refurbished in Italy. Now, 50% of the Italian generation is based on CCGTs. This obviously compares negatively versus countries like France and Germany, where cheap sources like nuclear and coal ignite generation is accounting for more than 70%.

In short, once more, one more year, let me repeat, Italian mix drives the generation cost of our country above Western European prices. It's a fact of life, my friends. Even though the CCGT investment is closing to an end, as a matter of fact, recently built CCGTs plants continue to have a fundamental role, as working – as they are working as capacity. And as a consequence, being most of the time marginal technology in the system, they had to take the price for it.
Based on the current forward oil price, standard CCGT pure variable cost will stay in the range of 60 euros per megawatt hour. And this will be, again, in the foreseeable future.

Power price are usually aligned to cost. Since CCGTs have been built in the last eight years, it is reasonable to expect that the Italian price will remunerate also the capital cost of these power plants as opposed to, for instance France and Germany, where most of the thermal power plants are all fully depreciated. This is why, one more reason, we believe that a robust spark spread premium is foreseeable in the Italian market, versus Western European markets.

This behavior of the market has been confirmed by the last 12 months. On a rolling basis, you take the last 12 months and you seek through what has been the spread. Well, no surprise, the spark market during these last 12 rolling months, delivered a base load spark spread above 17 euros per megawatt hour. I don't think I need to define what a spark spread is to all of you.

In the medium long-term, we expect Italian power prices to be aligned to full cost of a new CCGT delivering sound, clean base load spark spread in the range of 16, 18 euros per megawatt hour. And this is the 11th year I'm debating with you this point.

Coming to our activities in the free retail market, we are strengthening our position both in the power sector, where we maintain a market share of around 70%, and in the gas sector, where we have grown to a market share of around 15%. Our strategic focus will be to increase our customer base by more than 1 million customers per year leveraging on residential clients, small medium enterprises and leveraging on dual energy sales all of this grand resilience and margin protection. And this will be achieved thanks to continuous improvement quality and efficiency in operations.

Regarding Infrastructure and Networks, we will continue to be focused on OpEx and CapEx optimization and high quality standards. This will go together with maintaining our leadership position in technological innovation. Through smart grids we will enable renewables integration, energy efficiency program and electric mobility.

Let me now move to the international operations. Our core geographical areas are Slovak Republic, Russian Federation, Romania, France and these countries are going to remain key in the deployment of our CapEx program. In particular, in France, we'll continue to expand our nuclear activities by participating in the EPR projects with EDF, with a total investment of about 275 million euros during the period. In addition, we will continue to increase our supply market share with a target to sell almost 11 terawatt hours by 2014.
In Romania, we'll continue to invest, to improve quality standards of the electricity grid being focused on customer satisfaction and sharing of the Group's best practices.

Let me be a bit more specific about Slovak Republic and Russia. Let me start with Russia first. In Russia, we will invest about 1 billion euros over the period, mainly in improving our generation mix through the building of two new CCGT plants for a total net capacity of 800 megawatts. These new plant will partially benefit from a very competitively priced equity gas coming from our upstream division SeverEnergia. We expect to deliver the first gas out of SeverEnergia by 2011 and to ramp up production of equity gas up to six billion cubic meters a year at peak.

By the way, let me also announce that we have decided to create a corporate unit fully focused on developing upstream gas for the benefit of the whole Group. And this year it will also manage operations of SeverEnergia asset and we have Marco Arcelli who is leading this unit for us. On the regulatory side, the new long-term capacity payment mechanism will allow us to remain committed to our profitability target, even in a challenging economic environment.

By the way, as I say, energy consumption is increasing 7% for the first two months of the year. This is a good sign. This is because the payment based on capacity install and not on energy production. Based on capacity, not on production gives us an additional push towards that country.

Let me underline that the Russian market continues its path towards increasing gas price to the net back level, which is expected to be reached by 2015. And we take a conservative view about it. In particular, as of today, average market gas price stands at euros 47.6 per thermal cubic meter – 1,000 cubic meter, sorry.

Moreover, the liberalization process is well on track, and today 60% of the electricity market, excluding residential consumptions, has been already liberalized. Within this framework our investments in new CCGT will benefit of the higher margins in a market where prices are and will be settled by gas open cycles, less efficient technologies. In summary, Russia will continue to be a key market for us and delivery of growth will be mainly the result of commitment to efficiency CapEx.

Let me move to Slovak Republic, so Slovakia. In Slovakia we are completing the upgrade program on Units 3 and 4 of the Bohunice nuclear plant, increasing capacity from 858 megawatt to 956 megawatt. By the end of 2010, the plant's capacity will be further enlarged up to 1,000 megawatts.

Investment for the completion for Unit 3 and 4 at Mochovce nuclear plant continues to be a key priority. We expect the first 440 megawatts at Unit 3 to become available at the end of 2012 and the remaining Unit 4 during 2013. Our total capacity addition with these two new groups will be 1,000 megawatts.

Our planned global investment in Slovak Republic for the period is about 2.8 billion. All of these actions will allow us to reduce capacity constraints in that specific area and, therefore, to strengthen our position in the Centrel region. In addition, we will continue to reduce outages and optimizing maintenance to maximize the competitiveness of our generation fleet.

To conclude on Slovakia, let me underline how this acquisition represents a good example on how integration and consolidation is generating value for our stakeholders. Let me remind you that in about three years we have more than doubled both the EBITDA and the enterprise value of this company.

Let me comment now on Enel Green Power operations. Well, renewable energy has experienced relevant growth over the recent years in the entire world. As you know, at the end of 2009, there have been 1,230 gigawatt of renewable capacity installed worldwide. We expect this growth to continue in the future, to take place in all geographies. Europe, North America and Asia, we will lead the path.

With particular reference to North America, the Obama administration is generating a very strong impact on the development of this business. And we and Enel North America are already taking benefits during 2009 of this new policy. Having said that we strongly believe that a well-balanced technological mix is preferable to a mono-technology portfolio, I will continue to purport the case of Enel Green Power as a well-positioned company to attract and appeal investors.

Enel Green Power relies on the wind and solar photovoltaic to push growth and on geothermal and hydro to capture opportunities, while we'll continue to generate robust cash flows. Furthermore, our asset base could provide a strong and stable cash flow and to our pipeline will give an optionality lever.

Moreover, in a time featured by credit market's tightness, our growth over the period will be funded by operating cash flows. More specifically, our investment will be mainly focused on increasing wind and solar capacity, reaching 9.2 gigawatt in 2013, 2014, with a total investment of more than five billion euros, 5.1 as a matter of fact.

Innovation, again, will play a particular important role, a key role; in particular in the field of thermal, solar and concentrated photovoltaic. Things like the Archimedes Project will prove it. EGP will spend on its own, in addition to what we are spending as a group, about 50 million euros in R&D projects.
